abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Baron Herzog '99 chenin blanc from Royal Wine Corp of Brooklyn; photo (M)

block.p: Gold medals are showered so profusely in so many wine competitions that they equal in value the German marks trundled to banks in wheelbarrows during the Weimar Republic.
Besides, who knows how qualified the judges were and what standards and practices were used.
Gold medals are showered so profusely in so many wine competitions that they equal in value the German marks trundled to banks in wheelbarrows during the Weimar Republic.
Besides, who knows how qualified the judges were and what standards and practices were used.

Yet, certain wines are obvious winners. Take the charming Baron Herzog '99 chenin blanc, made in California by the Royal Wine Corporation in Brooklyn. (It's kosher, a fact relevant perhaps only to Orthodox Jews.)

This starlet, from a Loire grape that bafflingly has fallen from favor in North America, and is priced to sell nationally at $6, defeated 732 whites to win the title of best white wine of the show at the Riverside International Wine Competition in California in May.
Peter Stern, Royal's winemaker in California, has a sure hand with this grape: the '98 Baron Herzog chenin blanc was voted best white wine at the '99 West Coast Wine Competition in California.

In Scarsdale, the ubiquitous Herzog chenin costs $6.50 at Cheers, 1070-72 Wilmot Road; in Mamaroneck, $8 at Mamaroneck Station Liquors, 137 Halstead Avenue; in Riverdale, the Bronx, $6 at Fieldston, 3704 Riverdale Avenue (236th Street), and $6 at Skyview, in a shopping center at 5681 Riverdale Avenue (259th Street).

Light as chiffon, the chenin, fresh and quaffable, is as aromatic as a summer garden. It is round and dry enough to pour as an aperitif or to wash down fish, chicken and veal. When moderately chilled, at first sip it delivers a teasingly fruity opening punch line, which, as it warms up, yields to a quieter, more serious flavor narrative with a citric nip in the long finish.
